answers.author: Stephen Pauken
answers.text:
Hi Brian.  Since it's been 18 days, apparently there are not many.  Without legal counsel, I would venture to guess there would be issues with a policy that disqualifies one from employment for being a smoker (especially regulating what a person can do legally while off the job).  There are certainly good examples of regulating smoking in the workplace that make good, common sense.  Wellness programs are also available in many places so that employees who want to quit can get help.  I believe that is as much as you can do.

answers.author: Jill Silverboard
answers.text:
City of Clearwater (and many Florida cities because of state heart and lung presumption) have collective bargaining provisions that stipulate as a condition of employment nonsmokers for police and fire/rescue.  We currently have policy in place for no smoking while "on the clock" for all employees, but not an out right preclusion other than police and fire/rescue.
